Resource Assignment: 002.002.000*Struggle For A Continent: The French and Indian Wars: 1689-1763->Canadian History: Grades 5-6
Assignments_T2: Struggle For A Continent: The French and Indian Wars: 1689-1763 (Partial Term)
Resource_Information_Text:
Struggle For A Continent: The French and Indian Wars: 1689-1763 by Betsy Maestro
ISBN/ASIN 9780688134501 

➜ RATIONALE: Struggle for a Continent recounts the riveting story of the French and British dynastic conflicts over dominion of North American between 1689-1763. It allows students to locate the major events of this historical period in Canada - such as the fighting over New France, the sieges on Louisbourg, the Acadian Expulsion, and the Battle of the Plains of Abraham - within the context of wider intercolonial fighting throughout the continent.

Resource Assignment: 002.002.000*Escape: Adventures of a Loyalist Family->Canadian History: Grades 5-6
Assignments_T2: Escape: Adventures of a Loyalist Family (Partial Term)
Assignments_T3: Escape: Adventures of a Loyalist Family (Full Term)
Resource_Information_Text:
Escape: Adventures of a Loyalist Family by Mary Beacock Fryer
ISBN/ASIN 978-1895681178 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: Escape tells the story of the Seaman family's dangerous journey from New York to Canada to evade the vengeance of the American Revolutionaries who sought to prosecute and punish those who had stayed loyal to Britain during the Revolutionary War. The story is told from the perspective of twelve-year-old Ned Seaman, who, when his family separates into smaller groups to make the trip, must remain brave and quick thinking to avoid detection. The author, Mary Beacock Fryer, is a descendant of the Seaman family, who settled in Rockport, Ontario at the close of the eighteenth century.

ISBN/ASIN 978-0887766572 

➜ RATIONALE: In this remarkable book, illustrated entirely with paintings, archival maps, and original artifacts, the author brings to life this complex man and, through him, creates a portrait of Canada in its earliest days.

A History of US: The First Americans by Joy Hakim
ISBN/ASIN 978-0195327151 

➜ RATIONALE: This is a great spine to explore pre-Columbian history in the Americas through 1600. The author spends several chapters discussing the various native tribes that lived throughout the country. She helps students understand the context of Europe that brought explorers, treasure-seekers, Catholic missionaries, and new settlers to America.  Her engaging writing style and use of photos and maps will help students understand this time period.


NOTE: Canadian students will also be using this book since it covers the history of the Americas and ends in 1600 before the Jamestown Colony.

Lincoln: A Photobiography by Russell Freedman
ISBN/ASIN 978-0395518489 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: This book follows the events leading up to, during, and after the Civil War through the life of Abraham Lincoln. This is the first war during which photography was used to show the people back home what war was really like, so the images capture not only the events, but also the new technology of the age.

➜ RATIONALE: Focusing on the period from the ascendance of George III to the throne of Great Britain until the approval in the Continental Congress of the Declaration of Independence, acclaimed biographer Natalie S. Bober presents a bi-focal view of the events leading to the Revolutionary War -- telling the story through the eyes of the heroes and rebels involved on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean.

Breaker Boys: How a Photograph Helped End Child Labor by Michael Burgan
ISBN/ASIN 978-0756545109 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Lewis Hine documents working conditions and child labor in the early 20th century.

Resource Assignment: 001.004.000*Migrant Mother: How a Photograph Defined the Great Depression->U.S. History: Grades 7-8
Assignments_T1: Migrant Mother: How a Photograph Defined the Great Depression
Resource_Information_Text:
Migrant Mother: How a Photograph Defined the Great Depression by Don Nardo
ISBN/ASIN 978-0756544485 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Dorothea Lange documents the American Great Depression in the 1930s.

The Winter People by Joseph Bruchac
ISBN/ASIN 978-0142402290 
Alternate Formats: Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: This novel is set during the French and Indian War. It is based on real historical events, specifically the 1759 attack on St. Francis (Odanak), an Abenaki village in present-day Canada, by Robert Rogers and his rangers. The story follows Saxso, a 14-year-old Abenaki boy, who must embark on a perilous journey from his village to the New England area to rescue his mother and sisters after they are taken captive. Joseph Bruchac, who is of Abenaki descent, does a good job weaving elements of Native American culture, history, and values into the narrative. He also shows the influence of the Jesuits on the Natives, how Christianity influenced their lives, and their relationships with the French people.

George Washington, Spymaster by Thomas B. Allen
ISBN/ASIN 978-1426300417 
Alternate Formats: Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: This award-winning book delves into George Washington’s role as a master of intelligence, revealing how he used spies, secret codes, invisible ink, and double agents to outmaneuver the British. This book begins with the  French and Indian War in 1753 and continues through the end of the Revolutionary War in 1783. The engaging book tells about real-life spy stories and how key figures such as Nathan Hale, Benjamin Tallmadge, and the Culper Ring played a crucial role in winning the war against Britain.

Resource Assignment: 002.001.000*Colonization and the Wampanoag Story->U.S. History: Grades 7-8
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:
U.S. History: Grades 7-8
U.S. History: Grade 9
Canadian History: Grades 7-8
Resource_Information_Text:
Colonization and the Wampanoag Story by Linda Coombs
ISBN/ASIN 978-0593480434 

➜ RATIONALE: It is important to see history from different perspectives. Not only does it give us a more accurate understanding of the past, but it also helps us to learn the stories of other people who are fellow image-bearers. This book tells about the life and culture of the Wampanoag before colonists arrived in America. It also tells how their lives changed as a result of the new colonists. This book sets the Natives' story in context by presenting the ideas and worldviews that led to the demise of the natives' way of life. Although these ideas and questions can be hard to face, we believe these discussions are part of a Mason education as students learn the value of different points of view and gain an understanding of the complexity of history.

Up from Slavery by Booker T. Washington
ISBN/ASIN 978-0486287386 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: This is a first-person account of what it was like to be born on a slave plantation, live through the Civil War and Reconstruction, and make a new life as a free person. Washington's accomplishments and sense of hope are inspiring, and his founding of the Tuskegee Institute which continues as a historically black university and National Historic Site today is a remarkable achievement, even taking into consideration the later unethical research problems that have come to light in more recent years.

NOTE: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

➜ RATIONALE: Photographic history of John F. Kennedy's assassination and the smooth and orderly transition of power to Lyndon B. Johnson.

➜ RATIONALE: This is a wonderful biography of William Bradford, the governor of Plymouth Colony for 30 years. This book will help students have a deeper understanding of the Pilgrims and what life was like for them in Europe, both in England and Holland, that caused them to leave and start a new colony in America.  Their daily lives, their struggles, their relationship with the Native Americans, and their strong faith in God are clearly communicated in this book. 


NOTE: For Grades 9-10 World History, choose ONE of the biographies listed for Term 3.

➜ RATIONALE: This historical fiction novel that takes place in the 1660’s is based on true events and people from the town of Eyam, a small town in rural England. Resource_Information_Text:
The Ancient Near Eastern World by Amanda H. Podany & Marni McGee
ISBN/ASIN 978-0195161595 

➜ RATIONALE: This book is written by experts in their field yet it is accessible to students. The authors tell the stories of the scribes, lawmakers, kings, queens, farmers, and priests who lived in the ancient lands of Mesopotamia, Israel, and Babylon by tying in archeological finds and highlighting primary sources throughout the book.

The Ancient Greek World by Jennifer Roberts & Tracy Barrett
ISBN/ASIN 978-0195156966 
Alternate Formats: Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: This book is written by experts in their field who have a passion for their subject.  It tells about the people and events of ancient Greece while also including more recent archeological finds and highlighting primary sources. This book is a part of a great series that shows how the study of the past is a continuous process of weighing evidence, studying primary documents, and uncovering artifacts in order to illuminate what life was like for the people who lived before us.

Resource Assignment: 001.001.000*A History of US: The First Americans->Canadian History: Grades 7-8
Assignments_T1: A History of US: The First Americans
Assignments_T2: A History of US: The First Americans

U.S. History: Grades 7-8

Resource_Information_Text:
A History of US: The First Americans by Joy Hakim
ISBN/ASIN 978-0195327151 

➜ RATIONALE: This is a great spine to explore pre-Columbian history in the Americas through 1600. The author spends several chapters discussing the various native tribes that lived throughout the country. She helps students understand the context of Europe that brought explorers, treasure-seekers, Catholic missionaries, and new settlers to America.  Her engaging writing style and use of photos and maps will help students understand this time period.


NOTE: Canadian students will also be using this book since it covers the history of the Americas and ends in 1600 before the Jamestown Colony.

Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:
U.S. History: Grades 7-8
Canadian History: Grades 7-8

World History: Grade 9
Resource_Information_Text:
1493 for Young People by Charles Mann, Adapted by Rebecca Stefoff
ISBN/ASIN 978-1609806637 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: This book helps students understand both the positive and negative effects that resulted from the Columbian Exchange (the exchange of goods and people between the Old World and the New World during the Age of Exploration) in the 15th century. This thought-provoking book gets past the facts of history to explore the ideas that still affect us today. 

NOTE: Make sure to buy the Young Reader's Version. Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

Hudson's Bay Company Adventures by Elle Andra-Warner
ISBN/ASIN 978-1894974684 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: This book traces the history of the Hudson's Bay Company from its earliest days as a fur-trading enterprise started by the resourceful and canny pair of Radisson and des Groseilliers, to its establishment as a Canadian institution. Along the way we will meet a cast of memorable, yet largely unknown, characters, and learn how the story of the Hudson's Bay Company is inextricable from the history of pre-Confederation Canada: in particular, how it was shaped by events of conflict, compromise, and co-operation between various French, English, and Indigenous groups.

NOTE: Paperbacks recently went out of stock and we are in contact with the publisher to find out when to expect them back. In the meantime, there is a Kindle edition and a fair number of used copies available.

A Land Divided by John F. Hayes
ISBN/ASIN 9781927474693 

➜ RATIONALE: This Governor General's Award-winning novel is an exciting, adventurous tale about two cousins who get caught up in the French-English conflict of 1755 which would eventually lead to the tragic Acadian expulsion. This fast-paced novel features a sailing adventure, a daring rescue, and a spy plot, but on a deeper level, it shows how the line between the two sides was often drawn straight through families, as both cousins have an English and a French parent.

NOTE: The version used in this course is the recent edition which has been updated and abridged by Donna Ward.

Resource Assignment: 002.001.000*Colonization and the Wampanoag Story->Canadian History: Grades 7-8
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:
U.S. History: Grades 7-8
U.S. History: Grade 9
Canadian History: Grades 7-8
Resource_Information_Text:
Colonization and the Wampanoag Story by Linda Coombs
ISBN/ASIN 978-0593480434 

➜ RATIONALE: It is important to see history from different perspectives. Not only does it give us a more accurate understanding of the past, but it also helps us to learn the stories of other people who are fellow image-bearers. This book tells about the life and culture of the Wampanoag before colonists arrived in America. It also tells how their lives changed as a result of the new colonists. This book sets the Natives' story in context by presenting the ideas and worldviews that led to the demise of the natives' way of life. Although these ideas and questions can be hard to face, we believe these discussions are part of a Mason education as students learn the value of different points of view and gain an understanding of the complexity of history.

Shared_RollUp_Rotation 2:
Canadian History: Grades 7-8
Canadian History: Grades 9-10
Resource_Information_Text:
My Indian by Saqamaw Mi'sel Joe and Sheila O'Neill
ISBN/ASIN 978-1550818789 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: My Indian is a historical reimagining of a journey through Newfoundland that actually took place in 1822. William Cormack, an explorer and writer born in Newfoundland to Scottish parents, endeavoured to discover the last remaining Beothuk people, and requested the assistance of a Mi’kmaw guide, Sylvester Joe, whom he referred to as "My Indian" in his journals. This book recounts this journey from the perspective of Sylvester Joe, and includes engaging details about Mi'kmaq culture, history, and traditions. It also raises important issues about naming, identity, and respect.

Resource Assignment: 002.002.000*Voices of the Elders: Huu-ay-aht Histories and Legends->Canadian History: Grades 7-8
Assignments_T2: Voices of the Elders: Huu-ay-aht Histories and Legends (Full Term)
Assignments_T3: Voices of the Elders: Huu-ay-aht Histories and Legends (Full Term)
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 2:

Canadian History: Grades 9-10
Resource_Information_Text:
Voices of the Elders: Huu-ay-aht Histories and Legends by Kathryn Bridge
ISBN/ASIN 978-1927051948 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: Voices of the Elders is a compelling collection of oral histories, mythology, traditions, and historical events of the Huu-ay-aht First Nation, whose ancestral home is found at Barkley Sound, on the west coast of Vancouver Island. It is an accessible book that allows students to learn about this Indigenous community through their own words and stories.
For students also taking the Canadian option for Grade 8 Geography, this book is an interesting companion to Frances Barkley, since Barkley's voyage with her sea-captain husband was an early contact the Huu-ay-aht people had with Europeans, and that part of Vancouver Island was named for Barkley's discovery.

Assignments_T1: Queen Eleanor: Independent Spirit of the Medieval World
Resource_Information_Text:
Queen Eleanor: Independent Spirit of the Medieval World by Polly Schoyer Brooks
ISBN/ASIN 978-0395981399 

➜ RATIONALE: Born in 1122, Eleanor refused to be confined by the traditional gender roles of her time. She became well educated, gaining political and governing know-how from her father, William X, Duke of Aquitaine, and armed herself with the skills necessary to become an influential queen-first of France, and later, England. With an impact that reached beyond politics, Eleanor shaped the future of the arts and humanities.

Resource Assignment: 003.001.000*William Bradford: Plymouth's Faithful Pilgrim->World History: Grades 9-10
Assignments_T3: William Bradford: Plymouth's Faithful Pilgrim (Choose ONE of these biographies to read.)
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:
U.S. History: Grades 7-8
World History: Grades 9-10
Resource_Information_Text:
William Bradford: Plymouth's Faithful Pilgrim by Gary D. Schmidt
ISBN/ASIN 978-0802851482 

➜ RATIONALE: This is a wonderful biography of William Bradford, the governor of Plymouth Colony for 30 years. This book will help students have a deeper understanding of the Pilgrims and what life was like for them in Europe, both in England and Holland, that caused them to leave and start a new colony in America.  Their daily lives, their struggles, their relationship with the Native Americans, and their strong faith in God are clearly communicated in this book. 


NOTE: For Grades 9-10 World History, choose ONE of the biographies listed for Term 3.

✓OPTIONAL 
Pascal & Fermat by Robert Black
ISBN/ASIN 978-0898247060 

➜ RATIONALE: In the early 1650s, a French aristocrat posed a gambling question to Blaise Pascal, one of the most brilliant scientists and philosophers of the time. But even Pascal needed help. The idea of seeing the future—even seeing a possible future—was so alien that he needed to discuss it with someone else. So he contacted his countryman Pierre de Fermat, arguably the greatest “amateur” mathematician of all time. Over several months, the two men exchanged a series of letters that laid the foundation of what we know today as probability theory. 
There’s a “Doing the Math” section at the end of the book so that students can try working out the math themselves! This is a shorter read than some of the other options for Term 3.


NOTE: Choose ONE of the biographies listed for term 3.

✓OPTIONAL 
Galileo's Daughter by Dava Sobel
ISBN/ASIN 978-0802779656 

➜ RATIONALE: Inspired by a long fascination with Galileo, and by the remarkable surviving letters of his daughter Maria Celeste, a cloistered nun, Dava Sobel has crafted a biography that dramatically recolors the personality and accomplishments of this mythic figure.


NOTE: Choose ONE of the biographies listed for term 3.

✓OPTIONAL 
Here I Stand by Roland H. Bainton
ISBN/ASIN 978-1426754432 

➜ RATIONALE: Roland Bainton’s Here I Stand: A Life of Martin Luther remains the definitive introduction to the great Reformer and is essential reading for anyone seeking to understand this towering historical figure. This is a more challenging read for those wanting an in-depth look at Luther's life.


NOTE: Choose ONE of the biographies listed for term 3.

Resource Assignment: 003.001.000*Nine Day Queen of England: Lady Jane Grey->World History: Grades 9-10
Assignments_T3: Nine Day Queen of England: Lady Jane Grey
Resource_Information_Text:
✓OPTIONAL 
Nine Day Queen of England: Lady Jane Grey by Faith Cook
ISBN/ASIN 978-0852346136 

➜ RATIONALE: This book gives historical context to the biography of Lady Jane Grey, the woman who was Queen of England for nine days before being executed because of her faith. Lady Jane’s education, biblical training, and intelligence show how this young woman of sixteen could understand and hold firm to her beliefs even in the face of death. 


NOTE: Choose ONE of the biographies listed for Term 3.

ISBN/ASIN 978-1773101187 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: A work of creative non-fiction that is both personal and expansive in its scope, Acadian Driftwood recounts the Acadian Expulsion of 1755 through the experiences of the Leblanc family, which included ten siblings and their parents. The author is a descendant of this family, and only discovered his Acadian ancestry once he began to do genealogical research as an adult. This book makes an excellent history spine as it weaves the diverse fates of the family members into the larger conflicts, events, and developments of the latter-half of the eighteenth century.

NOTE: Option 2 link is for those purchasing from Canada.

ISBN/ASIN 978-0830825745 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Through the captivating story of the birth of this quintessentially American holiday, veteran historian Tracy McKenzie helps us to better understand the tale of America's origins―and for Christians, to grasp the significance of this story and those like it. McKenzie avoids both idolizing and demonizing the Pilgrims and calls us to love and learn from our flawed yet fascinating forebears.

ISBN/ASIN 978-1609806637

➜ RATIONALE: This book helps students understand both the positive and negative effects that resulted from the Columbian Exchange (the exchange of goods and people between the Old World and the New World during the Age of Exploration) in the 15th century. This thought-provoking book gets past the facts of history to explore the ideas that still affect us today. 

NOTE: Make sure to buy the Young Reader's Version. Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

Resource Assignment: 003.002.000*A Little Book for New Historians->World History: Grade 9
Assignments_T3: A Little Book for New Historians (Full Term)
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:
World History: Grade 10
World History: Grades 11-12
World History: Grades 7-9
Resource_Information_Text:
A Little Book for New Historians by Robert Tracy McKenzie
ISBN/ASIN 978-0830853465 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: Robert Tracy McKenzie offers a concise, clear, and beautifully written introduction to the study of history.  Loaded with concrete examples and insightful principles, this primer shows how the study of history, faithfully pursued, can shape your heart as well as your mind.

NOTE: Also highly recommended as a resource for parents and teachers.

Flight by Connie Brummel Crook
ISBN/ASIN 978-1554551903 

➜ RATIONALE: Connie Brummel Crook, a descendant of the Waltermyer family, tells the story of her Loyalist ancestors' dangerous journey to Canada to escape harm from American rebel soldiers intent on discovering British sympathizers. Hans Waltermyer, the family patriarch, secretly aided the British through intelligence, and the story is told from the perspective of his oldest son, George. Loyalists came from various backgrounds but played a significant role in shaping Canada before Confederation. Hans Waltermyer - who later took the name John Walden Meyers - went on to found the town of Belleville in the early nineteenth century.

Resource Assignment: 001.002.000*Voices of the Elders: Huu-ay-aht Histories and Legends->Canadian History: Grades 9-10
Assignments_T1: Voices of the Elders: Huu-ay-aht Histories and Legends (Full Term)
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 2:
Canadian History: Grades 7-8
Canadian History: Grades 9-10
Resource_Information_Text:
Voices of the Elders: Huu-ay-aht Histories and Legends by Kathryn Bridge
ISBN/ASIN 978-1927051948 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: Voices of the Elders is a compelling collection of oral histories, mythology, traditions, and historical events of the Huu-ay-aht First Nation, whose ancestral home is found at Barkley Sound, on the west coast of Vancouver Island. It is an accessible book that allows students to learn about this Indigenous community through their own words and stories.
For students also taking the Canadian option for Grade 8 Geography, this book is an interesting companion to Frances Barkley, since Barkley's voyage with her sea-captain husband was an early contact the Huu-ay-aht people had with Europeans, and that part of Vancouver Island was named for Barkley's discovery.

Shared_RollUp_Rotation 2:
Canadian History: Grades 7-8
Canadian History: Grades 9-10
Resource_Information_Text:
My Indian by Saqamaw Mi'sel Joe and Sheila O'Neill
ISBN/ASIN 978-1550818789 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: My Indian is a historical reimagining of a journey through Newfoundland that actually took place in 1822. William Cormack, an explorer and writer born in Newfoundland to Scottish parents, endeavoured to discover the last remaining Beothuk people, and requested the assistance of a Mi’kmaw guide, Sylvester Joe, whom he referred to as "My Indian" in his journals. This book recounts this journey from the perspective of Sylvester Joe, and includes engaging details about Mi'kmaq culture, history, and traditions. It also raises important issues about naming, identity, and respect.

Resource_Information_Text:
Acadian Driftwood: One Family and the Great Expulsion by Tyler LeBlanc
ISBN/ASIN 978-1773101187 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: A work of creative non-fiction that is both personal and expansive in its scope, Acadian Driftwood recounts the Acadian Expulsion of 1755 through the experiences of the Leblanc family, which included ten siblings and their parents. The author is a descendant of this family, and only discovered his Acadian ancestry once he began to do genealogical research as an adult. This book makes an excellent history spine as it weaves the diverse fates of the family members into the larger conflicts, events, and developments of the latter-half of the eighteenth century.

NOTE: Option 2 link is for those purchasing from Canada.

ISBN/ASIN 978-0674055636 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: History as seen through the lens of a famous ancient building.

Resource Assignment: 001.001.000*The Rosetta Stone and the Rebirth of Ancient Egypt->Ancient History: Grade 10
Assignments_T1: The Rosetta Stone and the Rebirth of Ancient Egypt
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:
Ancient History: Grade 10
Ancient History: Grades 11-12
Resource_Information_Text:
The Rosetta Stone and the Rebirth of Ancient Egypt by John Ray
ISBN/ASIN 0674063945 

➜ RATIONALE: Capturing the drama of the race to decode this key to the ancient past, John Ray traces the paths pursued by the British polymath Thomas Young and Jean-Francois Champollion, the "father of Egyptology" ultimately credited with deciphering Egyptian hieroglyphs. He shows how Champollion "broke the code" and explains more generally how such deciphering is done, as well as its critical role in the history of Egyptology. Concluding with a chapter on the political and cultural controversy surrounding the Stone, the book also includes an appendix with a full translation of the Stone's text.

NOTE: ALERT: Sensitive content. Lesson plans will provide guidance.

Civil War Hospital Sketches by Louisa May Alcott
ISBN/ASIN 978-0486449005 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: Primary resource of the well-known author's experience as a nurse during the Civil War.

Resource Assignment: 002.002.000*Founding Brothers: The Revolutionary Generation->U.S. History: Grades 10-12
Assignments_T2: Founding Brothers: The Revolutionary Generation (Full Term)
Assignments_T3: Founding Brothers: The Revolutionary Generation (Full Term)
Resource_Information_Text:
Founding Brothers: The Revolutionary Generation by Joseph Ellis
ISBN/ASIN 978-0375705243 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Six events bring to life the issues and individuals of the early days of the nation and students learn historical thinking skills by watching a master at work.

Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:
U.S. History: Grade 9
U.S. History: Grades 10-12
Resource_Information_Text:
The First Thanksgiving by Robert Tracy McKenzie
ISBN/ASIN 978-0830825745 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Through the captivating story of the birth of this quintessentially American holiday, veteran historian Tracy McKenzie helps us to better understand the tale of America's origins―and for Christians, to grasp the significance of this story and those like it. McKenzie avoids both idolizing and demonizing the Pilgrims and calls us to love and learn from our flawed yet fascinating forebears.

Resource Assignment: 003.003.000*I Am a Man: Chief Standing Bear's Journey for Justice->U.S. History: Grades 10-12
Assignments_T3: I Am a Man: Chief Standing Bear's Journey for Justice (Full Term)
Resource_Information_Text:
I Am a Man: Chief Standing Bear's Journey for Justice by Joe Starita
ISBN/ASIN 978-0312606381 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: The story of Ponca removal from Nebraska in the later part of the nineteenth century and Chief Standing Bear's fight for freedom in the U.S. Courts.

NOTE: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

Tomboy Bride by Harriet Fish Backus
ISBN/ASIN 978-1513262055 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: Subtitled: A Woman's Personal Account of Life in Mining Camps of the West.

Resource Assignment: 001.002.000*Vermeer's Hat: The Seventeenth Century and the Dawn of the Global World->World History: Grades 10-12
Assignments_T1: Vermeer's Hat: The Seventeenth Century and the Dawn of the Global World (Full Term)
Assignments_T2: Vermeer's Hat: The Seventeenth Century and the Dawn of the Global World (Partial Term)
Resource_Information_Text:
Vermeer's Hat: The Seventeenth Century and the Dawn of the Global World by Timothy Brook
ISBN/ASIN 978-1596915992 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Using the objects and people of Vermeer's paintings, the author delves into the cultural impact of the global trade routes.

The Red Palace by June Hur
ISBN/ASIN 978-1250800640 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: The Red Palace is a thrilling mystery that transports students to the secretive, dangerous world of the eighteenth-century Korean royal palace. The vivid descriptions, atmospheric writing, and carefully researched details about Korean culture and practices during this time period create a captivating world with memorable characters and a gripping plot. While on the surface the book is a page-turning detective story, the narrative probes deeper questions about identity, family, and revenge versus justice.

Resource Assignment: 001.001.000*Primal Myths: Creation Myths Around the World->Ancient History: Grades 11-12
Assignments_T1: Primal Myths: Creation Myths Around the World
Resource_Information_Text:
Primal Myths: Creation Myths Around the World by Barbara C. Sproul
ISBN/ASIN 978-0060675011 

➜ RATIONALE: A comprehensive collection of creation stories ranging across widely varying times and cultures, including Ancient Egyptian, African, and Native American.

I, Julian by Claire Gilbert
ISBN/ASIN 978-1399807524 

➜ RATIONALE: Compelled by the powerful visions she had when close to death, Julian finds a way to live a life of freedom - as an anchoress, bricked up in a small room on the side of a church - and to write of what she has seen. The result, passed from hand to hand, is the first book to be written by a woman in English.

NOTE: This book contains sensitive content. Lesson Plans will alert students and teachers to specific readings to allow for prereading, guidance, and discussion.  Students will gain insights into what it might have looked like to live for God in a different time and place.

World History: Grade 10
World History: Grades 11-12
Resource_Information_Text:
An Age of Voyages by Merry E. Wiesner-Hanks
ISBN/ASIN 978-0195176728 

➜ RATIONALE: This is a well-written and engaging book that is supported by wonderful illustrations and primary sources. The author does a great job of bringing to life a time of great changes in civilizations around the world. This book covers 1350-1600—the time of the plague, renaissance, exploration, turmoil in the church, and powerful empires around the globe.

Resource Assignment: 001.001.000*A Little Book for New Historians->World History: Grades 11-12
Assignments_T1: A Little Book for New Historians

A Little Book for New Historians by Robert Tracy McKenzie
ISBN/ASIN 978-0830853465 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: Robert Tracy McKenzie offers a concise, clear, and beautifully written introduction to the study of history.  Loaded with concrete examples and insightful principles, this primer shows how the study of history, faithfully pursued, can shape your heart as well as your mind.

NOTE: Also highly recommended as a resource for parents and teachers.

Resource Assignment: 001.001.000*The Rosetta Stone and the Rebirth of Ancient Egypt->Ancient History: Grades 11-12
Assignments_T1: The Rosetta Stone and the Rebirth of Ancient Egypt
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:
Ancient History: Grade 10
Ancient History: Grades 11-12
Resource_Information_Text:
The Rosetta Stone and the Rebirth of Ancient Egypt by John Ray
ISBN/ASIN 0674063945 

➜ RATIONALE: Capturing the drama of the race to decode this key to the ancient past, John Ray traces the paths pursued by the British polymath Thomas Young and Jean-Francois Champollion, the "father of Egyptology" ultimately credited with deciphering Egyptian hieroglyphs. He shows how Champollion "broke the code" and explains more generally how such deciphering is done, as well as its critical role in the history of Egyptology. Concluding with a chapter on the political and cultural controversy surrounding the Stone, the book also includes an appendix with a full translation of the Stone's text.

NOTE: ALERT: Sensitive content. Lesson plans will provide guidance.

➜ RATIONALE: Very readable biography of this important historical figure.

Resource Assignment: 002.001.000*Sunjata: Warrior King of Mali->World History: Grades 11-12
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:
World History: Grades 11-12
Lit./Mythology: Grades 7-8
Resource_Information_Text:
Sunjata: Warrior King of Mali by Justine Fontes, Ron Fontes, Sandy Carruthers
ISBN/ASIN 1580138918 

➜ RATIONALE: A young hero who overcame the unthinkable rises to unite his people. Weak and silent, young Sunjata is unable to walk, unable even to pull a bow. But a prophesy foretold that his mother would bear a son who will become the mansa of all the Mande people―the greatest king ever to rule. Sunjata rounds out Grade 7-8 students' study of mythology by introducing them to this ancient story from Western Africa through the authors' carefully researched storytelling and visuals. For Grades 11-12, this book serves as an introduction to orient students to the fuller narrative. 


NOTE: Budget tip: This book will be read over only a few lessons, so is an ideal title to get from the library.

Resource Assignment: 002.001.000*Sunjata: A New Prose Edition->World History: Grades 11-12
Resource_Information_Text:
Sunjata: A New Prose Edition by David Conrad
ISBN/ASIN 978-1624664946 

➜ RATIONALE: "After existing orally for hundreds of years, Sunjata was written down in the 20th century. David Conrad, who recorded a new version of the epic, has now crafted a prose translation that preserves the oral flavor of live performance. The result is a captivating work of literature that will finally give the story of Sunjata its well-deserved place among the great epics of world literature."

Resource Assignment: 002.001.000*Temples, Tombs, and Hieroglyphs: A Popular History of Ancient Egypt 2nd ed.->Ancient History: Grades 11-12
Assignments_T2: Temples, Tombs, and Hieroglyphs: A Popular History of Ancient Egypt 2nd ed.
Resource_Information_Text:
Temples, Tombs, and Hieroglyphs: A Popular History of Ancient Egypt 2nd ed. by Barbara Mertz
ISBN/ASIN 0061252778 

➜ RATIONALE: A fascinating chronicle of an extraordinary people—from the first Stone Age settlements through the reign of Cleopatra and the Roman invasions—Temples, Tombs, and Hieroglyphs brings ancient Egypt to life as never before. Lavishly illustrated with pictures, maps, and photographs, it offers tantalizing glimpses into Egyptian society; amazing stories of the pharaohs and the rise and fall of great dynasties; a sampling of culture, religion, and folklore; stories of explorers, scientists, and scoundrels who sought to unravel or exploit the ageless mysteries; and new insights into the architectural wonders that were raised along the banks of the Nile.

NOTE: ALERT: Sensitive content. Lesson plans will provide guidance.

Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:

World History: Grades 9-10
World History: Grades 11-12

Resource_Information_Text:
The Portable Medieval Reader by James Bruce Ross & Mary Martin McLaughlin
ISBN/ASIN 978-0140150469 

➜ RATIONALE: This anthology assembles an entire chorus of those voices—of kings, warriors, prelates, merchants, artisans, chroniclers, and scholars—that together convey a lively, intimate impression of a world that might otherwise seem immeasurably alien.

The Gilded Page by Mary Wellesley
ISBN/ASIN 978-1541675087 

➜ RATIONALE: The Gilded Page is the story of the written word in the manuscript age. Rich and surprising, it shows how the most exquisite objects ever made by human hands came from unexpected places.

NOTE: This book contains sensitive content. Lesson Plans will alert students and teachers to specific readings to allow for prereading, guidance, and discussion. The book does a great job of bringing the people behind the manuscripts to life.  A fuller understanding of the times is the result.

➜ RATIONALE: Shepherd. Warrior. King. Psalmist. Father. Fugitive. Hero. Villain. No single word is sufficient to encompass Israel's King David. The World David Knew offers a snapshot of life in 1000 BC.

➜ RATIONALE: Collection of primary source documents.

➜ May sub Free online sources.

Shakespeare's Restless World by Neil MacGregor
ISBN/ASIN 978-0143125945 

➜ RATIONALE: At the beginning of Henry V, Shakespeare asked his audience to 'Piece out our imperfections with your thoughts': but what mental world did the Elizabethans draw on to fill out the 'vasty fields of France', Cleopatra's barge, or Julius Caesar's forum? In this book, Neil MacGregor attempts to revisit the world of Elizabethan experience through discussions of objects including a communion cup, a rapier, a peddler's trunk, and a holy relic - traveling 'through the charisma of things, to a past world'.

Resource Assignment: 003.001.000*In the Beginning: The Story of the King James Bible->World History: Grades 11-12
Assignments_T3: In the Beginning: The Story of the King James Bible
Resource_Information_Text:
In the Beginning: The Story of the King James Bible by Alister McGrath
ISBN/ASIN 978-0385722162 

➜ RATIONALE: This fascinating history of a literary and religious masterpiece explores the forces that obstructed and ultimately led to the decision to create an authorized translation, the method of translation and printing, and the central role the King James version of the Bible played in the development of modern English.

Resource Assignment: 003.001.000*Mesopotamia: The Invention of the City->Ancient History: Grades 11-12

Mesopotamia: The Invention of the City by Gwendolyn Leick
ISBN/ASIN 978-0140265743 

➜ RATIONALE: Situated in an area roughly corresponding to present-day Iraq, Mesopotamia is one of the great, ancient civilizations, though it is still relatively unknown. Yet, over 7,000 years ago in Mesopotamia, the very first cities were created. This book brings those people to life.

Resource Assignment: 001.002.000*A History of Canada in Ten Maps: Epic Stories of Charting a Mysterious Land->Canadian History: Grades 11-12
Assignments_T1: A History of Canada in Ten Maps: Epic Stories of Charting a Mysterious Land (Selections)
Assignments_T2: A History of Canada in Ten Maps: Epic Stories of Charting a Mysterious Land (Selections)
Assignments_T3: A History of Canada in Ten Maps: Epic Stories of Charting a Mysterious Land (Selections)
Resource_Information_Text:
A History of Canada in Ten Maps: Epic Stories of Charting a Mysterious Land by Adam Shoalts
ISBN/ASIN 978-0143193982 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: This book tells the story of the discovery and development of the land that would become Canada by exploring the creation and usage of ten significant maps. It is an innovative and engaging approach to Canadian history, written by an academic and modern-day adventurer who has followed many of the routes taken by the explorers he includes in this book. It shows how history writing can create a more vivid representation of the past when it draws on biography, story-telling, geography, and cartography.

NOTE: This book will be used over two years in high school.

Shadows on the Rock by Willa Cather
ISBN/ASIN 978-0679764045 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Willa Cather's novel is set in the Quebec of 1697: a small, isolated settlement on a rock in the St. Lawrence River, surrounded by forest. It is a quiet novel peopled by those who found refuge in New France - fur traders, adventurers, merchants, mystics, nuns, and priests - and told through the eyes of twelve-year-old Cécile, who comes to realize she is more at home in Quebec than in the France her family left behind. This novel is an excellent supplement to the history spines, as the fictional characters occupy a historically accurate world, interacting with true historical figures and reacting to historical events. *This book has some outdated descriptions of Indigenous Canadians.*

Resource Assignment: 001.002.000*Making of Canada: An Epic History in Twenty Extraordinary Lives->Canadian History: Grades 11-12
Assignments_T1: Making of Canada: An Epic History in Twenty Extraordinary Lives (Selections)
Assignments_T2: Making of Canada: An Epic History in Twenty Extraordinary Lives (Selections)
Assignments_T3: Making of Canada: An Epic History in Twenty Extraordinary Lives (Selections)
Resource_Information_Text:
Making of Canada: An Epic History in Twenty Extraordinary Lives by Greg Koabel
ISBN/ASIN 978-1998365241 

➜ RATIONALE: In this engaging book, Greg Koabel challenges the notion that pre-Confederation Canada unfolded in a linear fashion, and instead suggests that nation-building involved greater "regional, national, and human diversity" than is typically acknowledged.  To illustrate this argument, Koabel introduces his readers to twenty episodes significant to Canada's history, but whose major players have been largely forgotten. These biographical vignettes give readers a more personal - and memorable - connection to Canadian history.

NOTE: This book will be published May 2025.
This book will be used over two years in high school.

Resource Assignment: 002.002.000*Acadian Driftwood: One Family and the Great Expulsion->Canadian History: Grades 11-12
Assignments_T2: Acadian Driftwood: One Family and the Great Expulsion (Partial Term)
Assignments_T3: Acadian Driftwood: One Family and the Great Expulsion (Full Term)
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 2:
Canadian History: Grades 11-12
Canadian History: Grades 9-10
U.S. History: Grade 9
U.S. History: Grades 10-12
Resource_Information_Text:
Acadian Driftwood: One Family and the Great Expulsion by Tyler LeBlanc
ISBN/ASIN 978-1773101187 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: A work of creative non-fiction that is both personal and expansive in its scope, Acadian Driftwood recounts the Acadian Expulsion of 1755 through the experiences of the Leblanc family, which included ten siblings and their parents. The author is a descendant of this family, and only discovered his Acadian ancestry once he began to do genealogical research as an adult. This book makes an excellent history spine as it weaves the diverse fates of the family members into the larger conflicts, events, and developments of the latter-half of the eighteenth century.

NOTE: Option 2 link is for those purchasing from Canada.

NOTE: Canadian students should purchase this book and NOT American Tall Tales for the Tall Tales/Fables course.

Resource Assignment: 003.001.000*The Door in the Wall->General Lit.: Grade 3
Resource_Information_Text:
The Door in the Wall by Marguerite de Angeli
ISBN/ASIN 978-0440402831 

➜ RATIONALE: An unforgettable story set in medieval times that will ease students into reading lessons for themselves and broaden their understanding of the year's time period.

Resource Assignment: 003.002.000*The Arrow Over the Door->General Lit.: Grade 3
Assignments_T3: The Arrow Over the Door (Full Term)
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 2:
General Lit.: Grade 3
Mythology/Hist. Fiction: Grade 4
Resource_Information_Text:
The Arrow Over the Door by Joseph Bruchac
ISBN/ASIN 978-0141305714 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: Beginning the connection between literature and history for our students in Grades 3-4, this story drops readers into the summer of 1777 with young Samuel Russell. The British Army is approaching, and the Indians in the area seem ready to attack. Meanwhile, Stands Straight, a young Abenaki Indian scouting for King George, knows the Americans threaten his family and home. When Stands Straight's party enters the Quaker Meetinghouse where Samuel worships, the two boys share an encounter that neither will ever forget. Told in alternating viewpoints, The Arrow over the Door is based on a true story.

NOTE: Grade 4 Students should choose this OR Seesaw Girl.

Resource Assignment: 001.001.000*In the Days of Giants->Mythology/Hist. Fiction: Grade 4
Assignments_T1: In the Days of Giants (Full Term)
Assignments_T3: In the Days of Giants (Partial Term)
Resource_Information_Text:
In the Days of Giants by Abbie Farwell Brown
ISBN/ASIN 979-8369898727 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: The Greeks were not the only ones with a story tradition that influenced Western culture. These Norse stories have also been highly influential, and Brown has retold them beautifully.

Resource Assignment: 002.003.000*Behind Rebel Lines: The Incredible Story of Emma Edmonds, Civil War Spy->Mythology/Hist. Fiction: Grade 4
Assignments_T2: Behind Rebel Lines: The Incredible Story of Emma Edmonds, Civil War Spy (Full Term)
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 3:
Mythology/Hist. Fiction: Grade 4
Lit./Mythology: Grade 5-6
Resource_Information_Text:
Behind Rebel Lines: The Incredible Story of Emma Edmonds, Civil War Spy by Seymour Reit
ISBN/ASIN 978-0152164270 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: In 1861 President Lincoln made an impassioned plea for volunteers. Determined not to remain on the sidelines, Emma Edmonds cropped her hair, donned men’s clothing, and enlisted in the Union Army. Posing in turn as a slave, peddler, washerwoman, and fop, Emma became a cunning master of disguise, risking discovery and death at every turn.

NOTE: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

Resource Assignment: 002.002.000*The Arrow Over the Door->Mythology/Hist. Fiction: Grade 4
Assignments_T2: The Arrow Over the Door (Partial Term - Choose this OR Seesaw Girl)
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 2:
General Lit.: Grade 3
Mythology/Hist. Fiction: Grade 4
Resource_Information_Text:
The Arrow Over the Door by Joseph Bruchac
ISBN/ASIN 978-0141305714 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: Beginning the connection between literature and history for our students in Grades 3-4, this story drops readers into the summer of 1777 with young Samuel Russell. The British Army is approaching, and the Indians in the area seem ready to attack. Meanwhile, Stands Straight, a young Abenaki Indian scouting for King George, knows the Americans threaten his family and home. When Stands Straight's party enters the Quaker Meetinghouse where Samuel worships, the two boys share an encounter that neither will ever forget. Told in alternating viewpoints, The Arrow over the Door is based on a true story.

NOTE: Grade 4 Students should choose this OR Seesaw Girl.

Assignments_T2: Seesaw Girl (Partial Term - Choose this OR The Arrow Over the Door)
Resource_Information_Text:
Seesaw Girl by Linda Sue Park
ISBN/ASIN 978-0547248882 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: Set in 17th-century Korea, this story introduces us to Jade Blossom, a young girl who spends all of her days inside her family's home grounds, as is the custom for all women and girls from wealthy families. Jade Blossom longs to see the outside world, and this propels her into mishaps and adventures, which gives students much to ponder about the nature of contentment, societal structures, foreign policy in 17th-century Korea, and more.

NOTE: Students should choose this OR Arrow Over the Door.

Shared_RollUp_Rotation 3:
Mythology/Hist. Fiction: Grade 4
Lit./Mythology: Grade 5-6
Resource_Information_Text:
Sing Down the Moon by Scott O'Dell
ISBN/ASIN 978-0547406329 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: The Navajo tribe's forced march from their homeland to Fort Sumner is dramatically and courageously told by young Bright Morning.

NOTE: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

Resource Assignment: 003.002.000*The Tales of Uncle Remus: The Adventures of Brer Rabbit->Mythology/Hist. Fiction: Grade 4
Assignments_T3: The Tales of Uncle Remus: The Adventures of Brer Rabbit (Selections)
Resource_Information_Text:
The Tales of Uncle Remus: The Adventures of Brer Rabbit by Julius Lester
ISBN/ASIN 978-0141303475 
Alternate Formats: Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Whether he is besting Brer Fox or sneaking into Mr. Man's garden, Brer Rabbit demonstrates that brains are better than brawn, along with other life lessons. These classic tales from the African American tradition are full of humor and creativity, and Julius Lester's retelling makes them a delight for readers today.

Assignments_T1: The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe (Full Term)

Resource_Information_Text:
The Last Mapmaker by Christina Soontornvat
ISBN/ASIN 978-1536230178 

➜ RATIONALE: A tale about character, integrity, and friendship in a time of exploration, mapping, and conquest. This book draws students into another world with rich storytelling and subtly enriches their historical studies as well because of its thematic relevance.

Shared_RollUp_Rotation 2:
General Lit.: Grade 4
General Lit.: Grade 5-6
Resource_Information_Text:
Johnny Tremain by Esther Forbes
ISBN/ASIN 978-0547614328 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Fourteen-year-old Johnny Tremain, an apprentice silversmith with a bright future ahead of him, injures his hand in a tragic accident, forcing him to look for other work. In his new job as a horse-boy, riding for the patriotic newspaper The Boston Observer, and as a messenger for the Sons of Liberty, he encounters John Hancock, Samuel Adams, and Dr. Joseph Warren.  Soon, Johnny is involved in the pivotal events of the American Revolution, from the Boston Tea Party to the first shots fired at Lexington.

Resource_Information_Text:
Nearer My Freedom: The Interesting Life of Olaudah Equiano by Himself by Monica Edinger & Lesley Younge
ISBN/ASIN 978-1728464077 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Nearer My Freedom retells Equiano’s remarkable life story in found verse, shaping his own words into striking and accessible poetry. Supplemented with detailed and illuminating annotations, authors Monica Edinger and Lesley Younge offer a fresh means to engage with one of the most famous texts of the abolition movement.

A Single Shard by Linda Sue Park
ISBN/ASIN 978-0547534268 

➜ RATIONALE: This book grows students' love for literature and history by immersing them in the life and riveting story of Tree-ear, an orphan boy in a 12th-century Korean potters’ village. Great for Book of Centuries work as well.

King of the Wind: The Story of the Godolphin Arabian by Marguerite Henry

Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: This beautiful story is partly historical fiction set during the early 1700s in Morocco, France, and England, telling the story of the thoroughbred lineage. But it is mostly a poignant tale of remarkable friendship between a boy and his horse.

Shared_RollUp_Rotation 2:
General Lit.: Grade 5-6
General Lit: Grades 7-8
Resource_Information_Text:
Treasure Island by Robert Louis Stevenson
ISBN/ASIN 978-1789431025 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: A swashbuckling pirate adventure story loosely set in the 1700s, Treasure Island tells of young Jim Hawkins, who, through disconcerting circumstances, finds himself in possession of a treasure map. When he shows it to a local squire, they decide to set out to follow it. However, unbeknownst to them, they have made the mistake of hiring the infamous pirate Long John Silver as part of their crew!

NOTE: Grades 7-8 should choose this OR the Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee

Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:
General Lit.: Grades 9-10
Lit./Mythology: Grades 7-8
Resource_Information_Text:
Beowulf: An Illustrated Edition translated by Seamus Heaney
ISBN/ASIN 978-0393330106 

➜ RATIONALE: One of the earliest English texts, Beowulf is the epic tale of the Scandinavian hero who saves the Danes from the monster Grendel. This translation and edition is readable, linguistically rich, and includes illustrations and pictures of artifacts that students can use for their Book of Centuries. 


NOTE: An audiobook is also available from Audible

Assignments_T1: The Story of the Amistad (Full Term)
Resource_Information_Text:
The Story of the Amistad by Emma Gelders Sterne
ISBN/ASIN 978-0486415376 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: This is the gripping true story of the 1839 uprising on the sea and the high-profile trial that followed. Were the Africans murderous mutineers and the rightful property of Spain, or were they free men taken illegally from their homes and only defending themselves?

Resource Assignment: 001.003.000*At the Back of the North Wind (Everyman's Library Edition)->Lit./Mythology: Grades 7-8
Assignments_T1: At the Back of the North Wind (Everyman's Library Edition) (Full Term)
Resource_Information_Text:
At the Back of the North Wind (Everyman's Library Edition) by George MacDonald
ISBN/ASIN 978-0375413353 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: In this Victorian fairy tale, MacDonald explores the themes of social injustice and the role of death in our lives. This edition includes the original illustrations.

Resource Assignment: 002.001.000*Stories from Chaucer Retold From The Canterbury Tales->Lit./Mythology: Grades 7-8
Assignments_T2: Stories from Chaucer Retold From The Canterbury Tales
Resource_Information_Text:
Stories from Chaucer Retold From The Canterbury Tales by Joseph Walker McSpadden

➜ RATIONALE: An age-appropriate enjoyable collection to introduce students to some of Chaucer's most famous tales.
Selected Essays

Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:
World History: Grades 11-12
Lit./Mythology: Grades 7-8
Resource_Information_Text:
Sunjata: Warrior King of Mali by Justine Fontes, Ron Fontes, Sandy Carruthers
ISBN/ASIN 1580138918 

➜ RATIONALE: A young hero who overcame the unthinkable rises to unite his people. Weak and silent, young Sunjata is unable to walk, unable even to pull a bow. But a prophesy foretold that his mother would bear a son who will become the mansa of all the Mande people―the greatest king ever to rule. Sunjata rounds out Grade 7-8 students' study of mythology by introducing them to this ancient story from Western Africa through the authors' carefully researched storytelling and visuals. For Grades 11-12, this book serves as an introduction to orient students to the fuller narrative. 


NOTE: Budget tip: This book will be read over only a few lessons, so is an ideal title to get from the library.

Resource Assignment: 002.002.000*Rip Van Winkle & The Legend of Sleepy Hollow->Lit./Mythology: Grades 7-8
Assignments_T2: Rip Van Winkle & The Legend of Sleepy Hollow (Partial Term - with Primary Source documents)
Resource_Information_Text:
Rip Van Winkle & The Legend of Sleepy Hollow by Washington Irving
ISBN/ASIN 978-1952433221 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Rip Van Winkle lives in Colonial New York. One day, he falls asleep - and stays asleep for 20 years. When he finally wakes, he literally finds himself in a different country, because he has missed the entire American Revolution! A classic tale from an American author born just before the turn of the 19th century.

➜ May sub any unabridged version of Rip Van Winkle (the Legend of Sleepy Hollow is not assigned in the lesson plans).

Across Five Aprils by Irene Hunt
ISBN/ASIN 978-0425182789 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: This is a gripping story about a family that is torn between the Union and Confederate causes--a common experience during the time. As relatives take up arms on opposing sides, the ones left behind can only wonder if such a fracture can ever heal.

NOTE: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

Little Women (Part 1) by Louisa May Alcott
ISBN/ASIN 978-0147514011 
Alternate Formats: Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Although this book is set during the Civil War and the family patriarch is off serving with the Union army, the story does not center on it. Instead, it follows four sisters as they grow and learn to live full and happy lives.

NOTE: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

Shared_RollUp_Rotation 1:
Lit./Mythology: Grades 7-8
General Lit.: Grades 9-10
Resource_Information_Text:
Seven Daughters and Seven Sons by Barbara Cohen, Bahija Lovejoy
ISBN/ASIN 978-0688135638 

➜ RATIONALE: Based on an Iraqi folk tale, this beautiful story takes students into the tents and caravans of merchants from Damascus to Baghdad, Tyre, and Sidon.  Told from the perspective of several different characters, the book is also a poignant story about friendship, personhood, and love.

NOTE: ALERT: Sensitive content. Lesson plans will provide guidance.

Assignments_T3: Thunder Rolling in the Mountains (Full Term)
Resource_Information_Text:
Thunder Rolling in the Mountains by Scott O'Dell
ISBN/ASIN 978-0547406282 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: As Americans settled farther and further west, conflicts with the indigenous people escalated to a point of crisis. This is the true story of the Nez Perce and Chief Joseph, who were ordered to leave their land and move to a reservation.

NOTE: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

Resource Assignment: 003.003.000*Around the World in Eighty Days->Lit./Mythology: Grades 7-8

Around the World in Eighty Days by Jules Verne
ISBN/ASIN 979-8741663370

Resource Assignment: 003.002.000*Nearer My Freedom: The Interesting Life of Olaudah Equiano by Himself->Lit./Mythology: Grades 7-8

Resource_Information_Text:
Nearer My Freedom: The Interesting Life of Olaudah Equiano by Himself by Monica Edinger & Lesley Younge
ISBN/ASIN 978-1728464077 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Nearer My Freedom retells Equiano’s remarkable life story in found verse, shaping his own words into striking and accessible poetry. Supplemented with detailed and illuminating annotations, authors Monica Edinger and Lesley Younge offer a fresh means to engage with one of the most famous texts of the abolition movement.

Runner in the Sun by D'Arcy McNickle
ISBN/ASIN 978-0826309747 

➜ RATIONALE: This novel of pre-Hispanic Native American life in the Southwest tells the coming-of-age story of Salt, a young Pueblo boy, as he seeks to save his village from disaster.

Calico Captive by Elizabeth George Speare
ISBN/ASIN 978-0618150762 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: This book, loosely based on a real diary, tells the story of Miriam, who finds herself captured by Native Americans during the French and Indian War. She is taken to Montreal, where she meets the prominent Du Quesne family. It is a coming of age story chosen for its captivating storytelling and ability to pique students' curiosity about other times and places.

Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: This riveting and sobering story introduces students to Tim Meeker, whose brother Sam enlists in the American Army and whose father supports the British. Based on real events and people, the narrative helps students struggle with the complexity of the American Revolution and it's cost and necessity.

➜ May sub Johnny Tremain (see Grades 5-6 booklist) if students are likely to struggle with the more challenging content and a few violent and disturbing scenes in My Brother Sam is Dead.

Resource Assignment: 003.002.000*Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee->General Lit: Grades 7-8
Assignments_T3: Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee (Full Term - Choose this OR Treasure Island)
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 2:
General Lit.: Grades 9-10
General Lit: Grades 7-8
Resource_Information_Text:
Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee by Robert Van Gulik
ISBN/ASIN 978-0486233376 
Alternate Formats: Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Despite the unfortunate cover image which you may want to edit, this book is a engaging novel featuring three interconnected detective mysteries written by an anonymous author in the eighteen century, over a hundred years before Sherlock Holmes! These stories were selected by the translator Robert Van Gulik because of their accessibility and interest to an English-speaking audience as well as their literary, historical, and moral depth. An expert on the Chinese legal code, Van Gulik portrays the customs of the time authentically but with sensitivity (witnesses were sometimes tortured to encourage confessions) and includes a helpful overview of the Chinese detective genre in his introduction. Morally, the story centers on Judge Dee who is faced with quandaries about how to uphold justice, treat everyone with respect and fairness, and live virtuously as a person both in authority and under authority - giving students a positive example to admire while also challenging their cultural norms.

NOTE: Grades 7-8 students may choose this book OR Treasure Island.

Assignments_T3: Treasure Island (Full Term - Choose this OR Celebrated Cases)
Shared_RollUp_Rotation 2:
General Lit.: Grade 5-6
General Lit: Grades 7-8
Resource_Information_Text:
Treasure Island by Robert Louis Stevenson
ISBN/ASIN 978-1789431025 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: A swashbuckling pirate adventure story loosely set in the 1700s, Treasure Island tells of young Jim Hawkins, who, through disconcerting circumstances, finds himself in possession of a treasure map. When he shows it to a local squire, they decide to set out to follow it. However, unbeknownst to them, they have made the mistake of hiring the infamous pirate Long John Silver as part of their crew!

NOTE: Grades 7-8 should choose this OR the Celebrated Cases of Judge Dee

Resource_Information_Text:
The Book of Rumi by Rumi
ISBN/ASIN 978-1571747464 

➜ RATIONALE: Short fables about common sense and everyday life by the famous Persian author and poet Rumi intrigue and instruct students and give them a glimpse of life in a medieval Persian and Islamic culture.

NOTE: Students will only read selections (younger students less and older students more) as some fables contain sensitive or inappropriate religious and/or moral content and will be skipped in the lesson plans.

Fierce Wars & Faithful Loves by Edmund Spenser, translated by Roy Maynard
ISBN/ASIN 978-1885767394 

➜ RATIONALE: Edmund Spencer, a 16th-century poet whom Milton considered to be a better teacher than the medieval theologians, wrote an epic tale of adventure, love, noble deeds, and faith. Roy Maynard's annotation gives helpful notes and background to help students enjoy this epic story of St. George and the Dragon.

Resource_Information_Text:
The Word Made Fresh by Abram Van Engen
ISBN/ASIN 978-0802883605 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: A new book which just came out this year, Van Engen lays out a beautiful relational approach to poetry which resonates deeply with Mason (one chapter is titled "Think of Poetry Like Friendship"). As he models a love for poetry and gives insights into how to enjoy, understand, and read poetry (or start on the journey!), students will continue growing their own delight.

NOTE: The first section of the book (the more practical part) is scheduled in the lesson plans, but we recommend the whole book - which concludes with a theological reflection on the value of poetry - as a resource for parents and teachers.

ISBN/ASIN 978-1491267493 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: Singing Bird: Molly Ockett: A Maine Legend captures colonial New England at its most turbulent time. With authentic historical detail and richly drawn characters, the book charts the life of one remarkable Native American woman who endures through unimaginable circumstances and continues to live today in the imagination of New Englanders.

NOTE: Students may read this book OR The Astonishing Life of Octavian Nothing

ISBN/ASIN 978-0763636791 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Set in Revolutionary Boston, this thought-provoking novel takes place at a time when Patriots battled to win liberty while African slaves were entreated to risk their lives for a freedom they would never claim. 

NOTE: The first of two volumes, students will read this work during Term 2 and then may finish it and continue on with the series as interested in their own time.

Students may choose this book OR Singing Bird.

➜ RATIONALE: Inspector Alan Grant of Scotland Yard, recuperating from a broken leg, becomes fascinated with a contemporary portrait of Richard III that bears no resemblance to the Wicked Uncle of history. A fascinating historical mystery novel and reflection on the nature of history and a perfect companion to Shakespeare's play which students will also read this year.

Pensées by Blaise Pascal
ISBN/ASIN 978-0140446456 

➜ RATIONALE: The Penseés is a collection of philosophical fragments, notes and essays in which Pascal, a theologian and mathematician, explores the nature of God, man, and the universe. Read alongside Descartes and other essays in the lesson plans.

NOTE: Students only read selections of the Penseés, so you may wish to access a free version online.
➜ May sub Free version online

Selected Essays

A Midsummer Night's Dream by William Shakespeare
ISBN/ASIN 978-1501146213 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: One of Shakespeare’s most popular plays, A Midsummer Night’s Dream is a comedy set in Greece during the 12th century. The magical setting of this play is the city of Athens and the nearby enchanted woods where fairies and their mischief reign in the moonlight.

NOTE: This is a good play for those who are newer to Shakespeare.

ISBN/ASIN 978-0394850108 

➜ RATIONALE: This is a book filled with funny and illuminating poems for kids, personally selected by the nation's first Children's Poet Laureate, Jack Prelutsky, and illustrated by Arnold Lobel of Frog and Toad fame. Collected from authors across the centuries, this anthology invites children to experience the delight and wonder of words.

A Library for Juana by Pat Mora
ISBN/ASIN 9781643790589 

➜ RATIONALE: This is a delightful picture book biography about the life of Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz and her love for books. Sor Juana, sometimes known as the "Mexican Shakespeare," wrote during the time of Anne Bradstreet and others at the end of the 17th century. 

NOTE: Option 2 link is a Spanish edition.

Assignments_T3: A Voice of Her Own (Full Term)
Resource_Information_Text:
A Voice of Her Own by Kathryn Lasky
ISBN/ASIN 978-0763660918 

➜ RATIONALE: Kidnapped from her home in Africa and shipped to America, a girl was purchased by the Wheatley family in Boston in 1761. She’d had everything taken from her, but Phillis Wheatley had a passion to learn. Amid the tumult of the Revolutionary War, she became a poet and ultimately had a book of verse published, establishing herself as the first African American woman poet. Although her poems are challenging for young students, Kathryn Lasky's short biography introduces them to this remarkable woman.

Denison Pre-Algebra by Denison Algebra
Alternate Formats: Video

➜ RATIONALE: Denison offers a complete high school math program with video lessons taught by a veteran teacher and homeschool dad for Pre-Algebra through Algebra 2. Pre-algebra only requires familiarity with the four basic functions (add, subtract, multiply, and divide). After Pre-Algebra, the course splits into two tracks for Algebra, Geometry, and Algebra 2: a track for students who don't have significant struggles but aren't enjoying math, and a Success track for students who struggle with math and need shorter lessons with more scaffolding.

NOTE: Choose this or Hands-On Equations
If following the Denison track, you only need to purchase this text for 7th-grade math. Use this in place of Hands-On Equations AND RightStart Geometry.

Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: These beautiful picture books take us on a walk through the biomes, introducing the various plants and animals we might encounter in various seasons. They are a lovely addition to your bookshelf, but scheduling in the lesson plans is flexible for those using their library.

NOTE: Links provide various options in this biome book series. Teachers should select one that is familiar to the student for Term 1 and one that will be less familiar for Term 3.

➜ RATIONALE: This beautiful picture book introduces students to an insect and its relationship with the environment. It is a lovely addition to your bookshelf, but scheduling in the lesson plans is flexible for those using their library.

➜ May sub any life-giving picture book preferred by the teacher that is about an insect within the context of its plant community.

Desert Giant by Barbara Bash
ISBN/ASIN 978-1578050857 

➜ RATIONALE: This beautiful picture book introduces students to the saguaro cactus, a keystone species in the desert biome. It is a lovely addition to your bookshelf, but scheduling in the lesson plans is flexible for those using their library.

➜ May sub any life-giving picture book preferred by the teacher that is about a keystone species within the context of its community.

Resource Assignment: 002.001.000*To Fly: The Story of the Wright Brothers->General Science: Grade 4
Assignments_T2: To Fly: The Story of the Wright Brothers (Full Term)
Resource_Information_Text:
To Fly: The Story of the Wright Brothers by Wendie Old
ISBN/ASIN 978-0618133475 

➜ RATIONALE: This book tells the story of an important technology that students have probably observed and maybe even used. Along the way, they learn how the Wright Brothers were driven by curiosity and inspiration and how they persisted to solve one of the biggest challenges of their day.

➜ May sub First to Fly by Peter Busby

The Elephant Scientist by Caitlin O'Connell and Donna M. Jackson
ISBN/ASIN 978-0544668300 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: Challenges arise when wild animals meet human communities. The scientist in this story not only observes elephants, but she also uses what she learns from them, along with what she already knows about sound waves, to collaborate with the local community to navigate such challenges.

NOTE: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

ISBN/ASIN 978-1328895721 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: The Asian longhorned beetle has devastated forest ecosystems in America. Students are introduced to basic forestry as they learn about the problem of invasive species. NOTE: Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Learning Ally with Audio.

ISBN/ASIN 978-0618494781 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: In this classic story, readers hear the story of a man who suffers an horrific railroad accident.  The resulting brain injury forever changes his life and produces one the most fascinating case studies that neuroscience has ever seen. Note that the author associates social ability and success with human value. Discuss with students as appropriate. 

NOTE: Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Learning Ally with Audio.

ISBN/ASIN 978-1556520808 
Alternate Formats: Ebook

Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

NOTE: Available on Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Learning Ally with Audio.

NOTE: Available on Learning Ally with Audio.

The Story of Science: Aristotle Leads the Way by Joy Hakim
ISBN/ASIN 978-1588341600 
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: This series situates facts and theories within their historical, political, and cultural context.  The author tells the story of science as a process of developing knowledge that is intimately tied to human society. Ms. Hakim challenges readers to consider differing viewpoints, so as to understand science with uncommon wholeness.

NOTE: Sensitive content. Teachers should pre-read and plan how to handle potentially controversial topics.

Available on Kindle and Learning Ally with Audio.

Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: One of the first naturalists to observe live insects directly, Maria Sibylla Merian was also one of the first to document the metamorphosis of the butterfly and the close relationships between insects and plants. In this richly illustrated nonfiction biography, readers meet the "mother" of ecology, a woman who flouted convention in the pursuit of knowledge.

NOTE: Available on Audible and Kindle with enhanced typesetting and Learning Ally.

It has been designed for a gentler transition to high school science, as well.

NOTE: Relevant supplies from the Grade 7 list are further detailed in the Table of Contents for the Lab Book. It is recommended that supplies are obtained either for the year or by term.

Resource_Information_Text:
✓OPTIONAL 
The LEGO® Architect by Tom Alphin
ISBN/ASIN 978-1593276133  ✓REFERENCE
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: Travel through the history of architecture in The LEGO Architect. Learn about styles like Art Deco, Modernism, and High-Tech, and find inspiration in galleries of LEGO models. Then take a turn building 12 models in a variety of styles.

Resource Assignment: 001.001.000*The Master Theorem: A Book of Puzzles, Intrigue and Wit->Afternoon Occupations: Grades 9-12 (Opt.)
Assignments_T1: The Master Theorem: A Book of Puzzles, Intrigue and Wit
Assignments_T2: The Master Theorem: A Book of Puzzles, Intrigue and Wit
Assignments_T3: The Master Theorem: A Book of Puzzles, Intrigue and Wit
Resource_Information_Text:
✓OPTIONAL 
The Master Theorem: A Book of Puzzles, Intrigue and Wit by M
ISBN/ASIN 978-0692189825  ✓REFERENCE

➜ RATIONALE: M's Theorems are not your average Sudoku or crossword puzzles. They're each completely unique, beautifully illustrated, "escape room"-like puzzles that’ll have you decrypting messages and tackling creative brain-teasers.

✓OPTIONAL 
Mini-Farming: Self-Sufficiency on 1/4 Acre by Brett Markham
ISBN/ASIN 978-1602399846  ✓REFERENCE
Alternate Formats: Ebook, Audiobook

➜ RATIONALE: This resource is for the more seasoned gardener who is interested in self-sufficiency and conservation.

✓OPTIONAL 
Mastering Hand Building by Sunshine Cobb
ISBN/ASIN 978-0760352731  ✓REFERENCE
Alternate Formats: Ebook

➜ RATIONALE: From pinch pots to coiled boxes to soft slab tableware, mastering hand building is a lifelong pursuit. This book covers all the foundational skills, with lessons for constructing both simple and complex forms from clay.

✓OPTIONAL 
Pottery for Beginners by Ruth Baldwin
ISBN/ASIN 979-8355327958  ✓REFERENCE

➜ RATIONALE: Unleash your inner creativity and master the art of pottery with this complete craft guide to the wonders of ceramics.
